awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2020 Annual Conference on Quantum Information Processing (QIP)
awd_abstract_narration:
The 23rd  Quantum Information Processing Workshop (QIP 2020) will be held in Shenzhen, China from January 4th to 10th, 2020. This workshop is the central event in the area of Quantum Computing and, more generally, Quantum Information Science, bringing together over 600 of the leading international researchers in theoretical aspects of quantum information and computation, and play a role as one of the most important venues for the groundbreaking research in theoretical computer science. Students attending this event receive a broad exposure to the most novel and exciting ideas and results in the field through contributed talks, poster sessions, rump sessions, tutorial sessions, and industry sessions. In addition, participation in this top conference is an excellent opportunity for young researchers to develop necessary research skills in presentation and collaborations. By enabling the attendance of students with financial difficulty and encouraging the diversity of the participants, this travel grant potentially has long-term benefits after QIP 2020 has concluded. 

This project funds the participation of 20 US-based students in this event. Participation at this meeting will enhance the research experiences for students and provide increased opportunities for new collaborations. Organizers seek to increase the number of student and postdoctoral participants by targeting women, undergraduates, and under-represented groups for participation. The aim is to support young researchers who might not otherwise be able to attend QIP 2020 due to financial difficulty as well as to encourage the diversity of the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant gave financial travel assistance to 21 U.S.-based young researchers in attending the premier international conference on theoretical quantum computation, the annual conference on Quantum Information Processing (QIP 2020) in Shenzhen, Guangdong, China. The study of quantum computation is a cutting-edge field bridging the fields of computer science, physics, and mathematics, and aims to develop the next paradigm of computing technology. 

This grant helped raise the U.S.’s international standing by sending qualified U.S. students to QIP, which, in turn, may lead to new collaborations with international partners across the fields of computer science, physics, and mathematics. This not only provided an excellent opportunity for training and learning, but also to network with top researchers from around the globe. This is vital to keep the U.S. as a forerunner in the field of quantum computation research. 

Twenty-one researchers from 15 U.S. universities received awards under this grant in order to help cover travel, lodging, and conference registration. The awards were distributed based on funding need, merit, and identification in underrepresented groups. Nine out of twenty-one awardees are from underrepresented groups. The awardees presented in total 14 talks and many posters in the program. Funds were disbursed so as to represent as broad a spectrum of U.S. institutions as possible.
